title-group.article-title: An updated checklist of marine gastropods of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman

FATEMEH AMINI-YEKTA & HENK DEKKER
An updated checklist of marine gastropods of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman
( Zootaxa 4957)

No part of this publication may be reproduced, stored, transmitted or disseminated, in any form, or by any means, without prior written permission from the publisher, to whom all requests to reproduce copyright material should be directed in writing.
This authorization does not extend to any other kind of copying, by any means, in any form, and for any purpose other than private research use.

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Here we review and evaluate the marine gastropods of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman based on published accounts. A total of 850 species belonging to 129 families have records in the Persian Gulf (585) and Gulf of Oman (648), of which 383 species occurred in both regions. We updated the taxonomy and deleted records with dubious identifications. The resultant checklist documents the currently known diversity of marine gastropods from the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman and provides a foundation for future studies of the biodiversity of these areas.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: Persian Gulf ,
Gulf of Oman
,
Gastropoda
, Mollusca , Checklist

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
During the latter half of the 20 th century and beyond, considerable attention focused on the mollusks of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman . These include reports by
,
,
, Sharabati (1981),
, Smythe (1982),
,
,
,
,
,
,
,
,
, Yonow (2012), Nithyanandan (2012),
,
,
,
,
. In addition, the gastropod fauna of the Iranian part of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman has been studied by several Iranian researchers. These include (in Persian)
,
,
, Vazirizadeh et al. (2012), Kohan & Badbardast (2012), and
and (in English)
,
,
, Kohan et al. (2012),
,
,
, Rezai et al. (2016), Oladi et al. (2018),
,
,
. Finally,
and
report the molluscan fauna of the Persian Gulf and Qeshm Island , respectively, in their books. Although most of these studies have not been developed exclusively for taxonomic purposes, they present a list of gastropod species from their study areas. In the meantime,
with 122 species,
with 60 species,
with 25 species,
with 72 species, and Rezai et al. (2016) with 32 species list the marine gastropods of the region more comprehensively.

Many mollusks of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman are not well documented and are only reported in very scattered publications. Generally, data on the biological diversity of the Arabian region and Persian Gulf are poorly reported or not easily available (Wehe & Fiege 2002). Besides, many reports lack (accurate) figures of the mollusk specimens studied and often contain erroneous identifications, resulting in questions about what species were actually represented. Fortunately,
present a comprehensive review of most of the studies of mollusks from this region that occurred prior to 1995. Here we compiled records of gastropods from later studies that were not included in
, combined them with records from
, and critically evaluated the taxonomy of species accounts to provide an up to date and comprehensive checklist of marine gastropod species from the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman . The checklist should serve as a foundation for future studies on the biodiversity and taxonomy of this region and provides an updated estimate of the gastropod fauna of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman .

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
The data presented in this paper are based on a review of all previously documented and accessible literature relating to the gastropods of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman from 1994 until now. Of the 49 studies considered in this review, 31 occurred in the Persian Gulf, five were in the Gulf of Oman (3 studies covered both regions), and 16 were regional or global. Published papers involved studies from Bahrain , Iran , Kuwait , Qatar , Saudi Arabia , and the United Arab Emirates . The book by
that is described above covers most of the studies on this region before 1995. Therefore, with some exceptions, we do not mention studies before 1995 in the table of species, separately. A checklist of gastropod species from the region is given in Table 1 . Only records of species that are named up to the species-level are included in this table. We used
as a reference for gastropod classification; genera and species are listed alphabetically within each family. The scientific names have been updated according to the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS 2020), but in a few instances a different opinion is proposed or a name was not found. In these cases, the description is added to the note column of the table. Species with obvious erroneous identifications have been deleted and the assumed correct names are presented in the list. In such cases, the reported names (and the numbers of these species in
, if they exist) have been added to the table to make all changes clear to the readers.

A total of 850 gastropod species belonging to 129 families are recorded from the Persian Gulf (585) and Gulf of Oman (648), of which 383 species occurred in both regions ( Table 1 ). The 129 families represent five subclasses: Patellogastropoda (3 families), Vetigastropoda (11 families), Neritimorpha (2 families), Caenogastropoda (73 families), and Heterobranchia (40 families). The subclass Caenogastropoda with 73 families and 618 species was the largest with 73% of the total taxa included in this study ( Fig. 1 ).
Planaxis savignyi Deshayes, 1844
was the species with the most records followed by
Euchelus persicus ( Martens, 1874 )
,
Lunella coronata (Gmelin, 1791)
,
Pirenella arabica D. Reid, 2016
, and
Tylothais savignyi (Deshayes, 1844)
. Based on published data, Epitoniidae and Muricidae (with 46 and 45 species respectively) dominated in both regions.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman reports on Mollusca are sporadic and inconsistent. The available data are sparse and have not been generated by comparable sampling methods and consistent taxonomy. In addition, as stated by Wafar et al. (2011), the status of knowledge about coastal and marine biodiversity within the Indian Ocean is not uniform among countries which is likely due to the lack of human, institutional, and technical capabilities in some countries. Generally, the biodiversity of the northwestern Indian Ocean is poorly documented. However, the fauna of the Persian Gulf is better known than the Gulf of Oman .

Although the number of studies focusing on the Gulf of Oman was considerably lower than those of the Persian Gulf, the number of reported species from the Gulf of Oman was higher. Considering the moderate environmental conditions of the Gulf of Oman in contrast to the extreme conditions (in terms of temperature and salinity) of the Persian Gulf (Sheppard et al. 2010), the high biodiversity recorded in the Gulf of Oman , despite the low ratio of studies in this area to the total number of studies considered in this review, can be explained. Besides,
contributed largely to the number of species reported from the Gulf of Oman . Moreover, the result obtained from this review agrees with the findings of Amini Yekta et al. (2019) who report higher species richness in stations located in the Gulf of Oman compared to those of the Persian Gulf. They compared the abundance and biodiversity of intertidal rocky gastropods in five locations across the northern Persian Gulf (3 locations) and Gulf of Oman (2 locations).

Of the 850 gastropod species listed in this review, 689 (81%) are recorded in the book by
, of which 359 species are exclusively reported in this book from the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman . The Iranian researchers reported 258 (30%) gastropod species from the northern Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman , of which 56 species are exclusively found in these reports. While Iran occupies the majority of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman , approximately 43% of the studies were carried out by Iranian researchers ( Fig. 2 ). The extensive Iranian coastline ( 2250 km ) (Pak & Farajzadeh 2007) compared with other coastal states of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman can explain the high contribution of Iranian researchers to the published documents on the gastropod biodiversity of the region. Moreover, published documents in Persian are also considered in this review while only the published documents in English are collected from other countries. Despite the relatively high number of studies conducted by Iranian researchers, the diversity of mollusks on the Iranian side of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman is not yet estimated accurately due to the aforementioned problem in data collection: sporadicity and inconsistency of data. Besides, most of these studies have been developed for a specific purpose and the data accuracy in species identification varied greatly among data-collection practitioners (Hammond 1995).

The number of species in the region will certainly change with re-examination of previously identified specimens, as well as completion of the identification of collected specimens reported at higher taxonomic levels. For instance,
report the species belonging to Siphonariidae and Onchidiidae as
Siphonaria
spp. and Onchidiidae spp., respectively which were omitted in this review. Generally, onchidiids of this region have been reported as
Peronia peronii (Cuvier, 1804)
while systematics of the family Onchidiidae has been in a state of confusion for a while (
). Fortunately, the taxonomy of the genus
Peronia
is revised for the first time based on a large collection of fresh material by
. The records of
P. peronii
from the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman are probably
Peronia verruculata ( Cuvier, 1830 )
or
Peronia madagascariensis (Labbé, 1934)
, as
P. peronii
is not known from the area (
). Maneie et al. (2020) recently reported a new species of
Peronia
from the Persian Gulf as
Peronia persiae Maniei, Espeland, Mohavedi & Wägele, 2020
, while
regards it as a synonym of
P. verruculata
. In some cases, the identifications have been questioned by recent research, especially molecular phylogenetic analysis. Based on the review of morphological analyses of color pattern, radular structure, buccal mass, and reproductive system by
, the species
Glossodoris pallida (Rüppell & Leuckart, 1830)
which was originally described from the Red Sea and then also from the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman is a misidentification of the newly described species
Glossodoris buko Matsuda & Gosliner, 2018
. Another example of mistaken identity is the species
Aplysia parvula Mörch, 1863
which includes four genetically distinct lineages that include a total of ten different species (
). There are two new species names introduced for specimens considered to belong to
A. parvula
from the Indian Ocean:
Aplysia ghanimii Golestani, Crocetta, Padula, Camacho, Langeneck, Poursanidis, Pola, Yokeş, Cervera, Jung, Gosliner, Araya, Hooker, Schrödl & Valdés, 2019
and
Aplysia nigrocincta E. von Martens, 1880
. Further studies are required to choose the correct name for
Aplysia
records from the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman . Another example is
Ergalatax junionae Houart, 2008
which is found in large numbers in the Persian Gulf, southern Arabia, and at least until Pakistan and Gujarat and is locally very common in the intertidal zone but is mistakenly identified as
Semiricinula konkanensis ( Melvill, 1893 )
in many published documents.
S. konkanensis
is a valid species from India , a totally blackish species, rather uncommonly seen (H. Dekker, pers. obs.). A Pacific species
Nassarius albescens (Dunker, 1846)
is another example of erroneous identification which is recorded from the Persian Gulf. However, the supposed subspecies
Nassarius albescens gemmuliferus (A. Adams, 1852 )
which has been accepted as
Nassarius gemmuliferus (A. Adams, 1852 )
occurs in the Indian Ocean.
Nassarius fenistratus (Marrat, 1877)
is the valid name for what was once called
N. albescens gemmuliferus
. The “real”
N. gemmuliferus
is exclusively known from India (
).

Meanwhile, studies on mollusks of this region have often been performed in intertidal areas and so more diverse subtidal ecosystems, particularly coral reefs and seagrass beds, need more attention. In these ways, the diversity of gastropods in this region can be described more accurately.
